datasets.name: Drought
datasets.content: Drought Risk including the Combined Drought Indicator based on SPI, Soil Moisture Anomaly and fAPAR Anomly. Identify areas with potential to suffer agricultural and meteorological drought and areas where the vegetation is already affected by drought.

layers.name: Combined Drought Indicator
layers.description: The Combined Drought Indicator is based on SPI, Soil moisture and fAPAR, to identify areas with potential to suffer agricultural drought, areas where the vegetation is already affected by drought conditions, and areas in recovery process to normal conditions after a drought episode

items.name: Alert: Vegetation stress following rainfall/ soil moisture deficit

datasets.name: Vegetation
datasets.content: Keep track of vegetation photosyntetic activity and it's relation to agricultural drought using fAPAR and fAPAR Anomaly layers

layers.name: FAPAR Anomaly (Photosynthetic activity)
layers.description: The Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FAPAR) is biophysical variable, derived from satellite observations, that represents the fraction of incident solar radiation that is absorbed by land vegetation for photosynthesis.

layers.name: fAPAR Absorbed (Photosynthetic Activity)
layers.description: The fAPAR Anomaly is used in Detecting and monitoring the impacts of agricultural drought on the growth and productivity of vegetation

datasets.name: Soil Moisture
datasets.content: Using Soil Moisture Anomaly data , determine the start and duration of agricultural drought conditions arising from soil moisture availablity to plants dropping to a level that it adversely affects crop yeild.

layers.name: Soil Moisture Anomaly
layers.description: The Soil Moisture Anomaly is used in determining the start and duration of agricultural drought conditions, which arise when soil moisture availability to plants drops to such a level that it adversely affects crop yield, and hence, agricultural production.

datasets.name: Rainfall
datasets.content: Monitor monthly precipitation and Standardized Precipitation Index comparing the total precipitation received at a particular location during a period of n months with the long-term precipitation distribution for the same period of time at that location (reference period is 1981-2010).

layers.name: Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI)
layers.description: The SPI is a statistical index comparing the total precipitation received at a particular location during a period of n months with the long-term precipitation distribution for the same period of time at that location (reference period is 1981-2010). Monthly accumulation periods (n) are 1, 3, 6, 9, 12, 24 or 48 months
